awd_titl_txt: QII-TAQS: Characterizing and Utilizing 2D van der Wals Materials with Superconducting Qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information technologies hold the promise to revolutionize sensing, communication, and computing. Realizing this promise requires new approaches for creating "quantum-ready" materials and manufacturing processes. The research part of this project introduces a new class of materials called "van der Waals heterostructures" to the manufacturing of high-quality devices for application to quantum computation. Van der Waals heterostructures are a family of layered, two-dimensional (flat) materials that - depending on their design - may assume a wide range of properties, such as being a normal metal like copper, a superconductor like aluminum, or an insulator like aluminum oxide. The advantage of these materials is that they are crystalline and, therefore, have few (if any) defects. The atomically sharp interfaces of these heterostructures also provide a materials platform to build novel electronic devices. Defects limit the utility of  today's quantum devices, and this research aims to improve quantum device performance by leveraging their crystallinity. The research includes characterization of the electrical and optical properties of van der Waals heterostructures, as well as their use to manufacture and test a range of quantum devices useful for quantum information processing. The project also contributes to the training of a new generation of "quantum engineers" who will translate this work into industrial settings. The investigators are committed to the mentoring and training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates - the next generation of science and engineering leaders - as well as outreach to those already in the workforce and other members of the public. 

This project addresses the characterization of van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures - a family of layered, crystalline, two-dimensional (2D) quantum materials including semi-metals, insulators, semiconductors, ferromagnets, superconductors, and topological insulators - and their application to quantum information technologies. While vdW materials have been extensively studied via DC transport, few experiments have probed their quantum properties in the microwave and optical regimes relevant for quantum technology applications. In this work, the research team investigates 2D vdW materials using coherent optical techniques spanning microwaves, terahertz, and optical frequencies, including direct excitation and the use of circuit quantum electrodynamics with superconducting resonators to mediate fast, ultra-sensitive pump-probe experiments and detection. The team aggregates complementary expertise in vdW materials, high-quality-factor superconducting resonators, high coherence superconducting qubits, and their integration with vdW heterostructures. Fabrication of these devices leverages a unique, state-of-the-art hermetic device foundry developed in-house, as well as state of-the-art superconducting resonator and qubit fabrication. Measurements are performed at millikelvin temperature in cryogen-free dilution refrigerators with microwave and optical access. The research targets transformative quantum information applications, including high-coherence qubits, small-form-factor microwave components, and the study of quantum spin models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our collaborative research under the NSF QII-TAQS program has harnessed the extraordinary properties of 2D materials to develop innovative quantum technologies and advance fundamental sciences. By exploring the unique behaviors of various 2D materials --- hexagonal boron nitride, twisted multi-layer graphene, layered superconductors, and other van der Waals heterostructures, we aim to unlock transformative applications in computing, sensing, and the underlying physics. These breakthroughs have deepened our understanding of quantum materials and brought us closer to practical, scalable quantum solutions that could revolutionize technology.

William D. Oliver group:

Our research focuses on leveraging the unique properties of 2D materials to advance superconducting quantum technologies. We have demonstrated hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) as a low-loss dielectric in the microwave regime, enabling its application in van der Waals (vdW)-based Josephson junctions and transmon qubits. This approach allows for a footprint reduction of a single transmon qubit by at least 100-fold, paving the way for compact, high-coherence superconducting circuit elements that are crucial for the development of multi-qubit devices in the future.

We developed a novel measurement scheme combining DC and high-frequency techniques to investigate superconductivity in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene (MATBG). By probing the kinetic inductance, we confirmed that MATBG's superfluid stiffness aligns with quantum geometry theory, complementary to traditional Fermi liquid descriptions. This experiment also reveals an anisotropic superconducting gap, offering critical insights into pairing mechanisms in the moiré superconductors.

Furthermore, we characterized NbSe2 thin films and demonstrated their potential as a high-kinetic-inductance superconductor, also known as superinductor, for superconducting qubits with a long lifetime. These studies underscore the promise of 2D superconductors for creating high-quality circuit elements for quantum computing. Through these works, we have advanced the understanding of quantum materials, established new methods for studying 2D superconductors, and developed foundational technologies for extensible quantum computing architectures.


Pablo Jarillo-Herrero group:

Our research has made significant strides in advancing superconducting quantum devices, graphene-based technologies, and high-temperature superconducting photodetectors. By constructing a novel superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID), we uncovered a two-level quantum system with dissipationless components, paving the way for innovative quantum technologies. We also demonstrated voltage-tunable superconducting qubits featuring high coherence times, showcasing their potential for energy-efficient cryogenic circuits.

In graphene systems, we discovered groundbreaking magnetoplasmonic phenomena, revealing ultra-slow Bernstein modes that amplify light-matter interactions. These findings redefine our understanding of nonlocal optoelectronic responses and hold promise for next-generation infrared and terahertz technologies.

Additionally, we fabricated single-photon detectors using high-temperature superconductors such as BSCCO, achieving sensitivity at telecommunications wavelengths well above liquid helium temperatures. This breakthrough brings us closer to scalable quantum applications operating at practical temperature ranges.

Our work expands the material landscape for quantum and optoelectronic applications while also providing deep insights into the fundamental mechanisms driving these technologies. By combining experimental innovation with theoretical advancements, we are opening new avenues for both applied and fundamental research, with implications for computing, communication, and sensing technologies.

Philip Kim group:

Superconductivity, magnetism, and the fractional quantum Hall effect are emergent physical phenomena that result from the interactions of electrons, each of which represents a uniquely different extreme state of matter. Superconductivity arises from the pairing of electrons due to an attractive interaction that results in a macroscopic quantum state of perfect conductance. This state, whose charge carrier is a Cooper pair with twice the charge of the electron, is stabilized at low temperatures and low magnetic fields. Magnetism arises from the exchange interaction between electrons, where the Coulomb interaction of the electron charge provides an effective interaction between the spins. The fractional quantum Hall state, on the other hand, arises from repulsive interactions, and the resulting collective state conducts only at its edges with carriers that are a fraction of an electron charge, both of which are unique properties of this state. While the fractional quantum Hall state also requires low temperatures, it also requires ultrapure materials and extreme magnetic fields, in apparent conflict with superconductivity. The motivation to combine these extreme states of matter comes from parafermions - the hypothetical zero-energy modes predicted in a system where superconductivity, magnetism, and the fractional quantum Hall effect coexist. This combination is a new type of topological superconductor with distinct advantages over all previously demonstrated topological superconductors. In this work, we investigate the hybrid superconductivity of 2D materials with the aim of demonstrating fault-tolerant superconducting qubits.

In conclusion, supported by the QII-TAQS program, our team has made significant advances in quantum science and technology by leveraging 2D materials to develop transformative innovations. From pioneering superconducting qubits and photodetectors to uncovering groundbreaking insights into quantum geometry and topological superconductivity, our efforts underscore the potential of 2D materials for scalable quantum computing and sensing. These achievements establish a strong foundation for the future of quantum innovation.
